JDBC Consumer originSQL querySQL queryJDBC CponsumerThe SQL query defines the data returned from the database. When you define the SQL query, use the following guidelines:
In the WHERE clause, include the offset column and the offset value JDBC Consumer uses an offset column and value to determine the data that is returned. Include both in the WHERE clause of the query.
Use ${OFFSET} to represent the offset value In the WHERE clause, use ${OFFSET} to represent the offset value. For example, when you start a pipeline, the following query returns all data from the table where the data in the offset column is greater than the initial offset value. SELECT * FROM <tablename> WHERE <offset column> > ${OFFSET}When the offset values are strings, enclose ${OFFSET} in single quotation marks.
In the ORDER BY clause, include the offset column as the first column. To avoid returning duplicate data, use the offset column as the first column in the ORDER BY clause.
Using column that is not a primary key or indexed column in the ORDER BY clause can slow performance.
